description: From Middle English gaude, gawde (“jest, prank, trick; ornamental bead in a rosary, trinket, bauble”). Compare Middle English gaudy, gaudee, of the same meaning.

examples: A Libyan longing took us, and we would have chosen, if we could, to bear a strand of grotesque beads, or a handful of brazen gauds, and traffic them for some sable maid with crisp locks, whom, uncoffling from the captive train beside the desert, we should make to do our general housework forever, through the right of lawful purchase.

verbs.description: gaud (third-person singular simple present gauds, present participle gauding, simple past and past participle gauded)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To bedeck gaudily; to decorate with gauds or showy trinkets or colours; to paint.

verbs.description: gaud (third-person singular simple present gauds, present participle gauding, simple past and past participle gauded)
